CONCLUSION: No violation of Art. 11 or 11+10;Not necessary to examine P1-3

TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant party is established as an association registered on the basis of LAW of DATE . Its name in NORP is PERSON – PERSON ( NORP Nationalist Party – Iparralde Regional Organisation ) , and its registered office is in GPE ( GPE ) . “ GPE ” is the NORP designation for part of south - western GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant party applied to the ORG to reconsider its decision . The application was refused on DATE in a decision worded as follows :
As to the [ alleged ] absence of a ban on the financing of a NORP political party by a foreign political party :

Having compared the provisions of Article L. CARDINAL - CARDINAL of LAW , applicable to election campaigns , and LAW CARDINAL of the LAW DATE , the applicant contends that section DATE ... simply states that only a political party can fund another political party and that , contrary to the position regarding election campaigns , no provision of any statute or regulations expressly prohibits the funding of a political party by another political party established under the law of a foreign country .

This argument disregards the fifth subsection of section CARDINAL of the LAW DATE , as amended by the Acts of DATE and DATE , which provides : ‘ No funding association or financial agent may receive direct or indirect contributions or material assistance from a foreign ORG or a foreign legal entity.’

Substantive legality

The applicant group argues that the Commission erred in its application of section CARDINAL of the Act of DATE and that , should the ORG ’s interpretation be held to prevail , the statutory provisions cited in support of its decision should be struck down as being contrary to the LAW and incompatible with GPE ’s international obligations .
As to the alleged erroneous application of LAW of DATE :

... the penultimate subsection of LAW of DATE prohibits funding associations from receiving financial contributions ‘ from a foreign ORG or a foreign legal entity’ . Foreign political parties , which belong to the category of foreign legal entities , fall within the purview of that prohibition . The amendments resulting from the LAW of DATE to the second subsection of section CARDINAL - CARDINAL with the effect , firstly , of prohibiting a legal entity from funding a party or a political group and , secondly , of excluding ‘ political parties and PERSON from this prohibition on account of the role conferred on them by LAW had neither the purpose nor the effect of exempting foreign political parties from the prohibition on the funding of a NORP political party by any foreign legal entity . As to the alleged incompatibility of the law with GPE ’s international obligations :
As regards LAW :

The applicant group relies on ORG , paragraph CARDINAL , of which secures freedom of expression to everyone ‘ without interference by public authority and regardless of borders’ and LAW that the enjoyment of the rights and freedoms set forth in the Convention is to be secured ‘ without [ discrimination ] on any ground such as ... national ... origin ... ’ .

Even accepting , as the applicant group argues , that the rules on the conditions for funding political parties have a bearing on the right to freedom of expression within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL of LAW , which includes , as well as the freedom to hold opinions , ‘ the freedom to receive and impart information and PERSON , paragraph CARDINAL of the same Article nonetheless provides that ‘ [ CARDINAL exercise of these freedoms , since it carries with it duties and responsibilities’ , may be subject to such ‘ restrictions ... as are prescribed by law and are necessary in a democratic society’ to the extent that they satisfy CARDINAL or other of the requirements set forth in that paragraph , among which is ‘ the prevention of disorder’ .

Political groups and parties falling within the purview of LAW are intended to contribute to the exercise of suffrage in the implementation of national sovereignty . In prohibiting foreign GPE and foreign legal entities from funding national political parties , the legislature sought to preclude the possibility of creating a relationship of dependency which would be detrimental to the expression of national sovereignty . The aim thus pursued is linked to the ‘ prevention of disorder’ within the meaning of paragraph CARDINAL of LAW . On account of both the justification of this measure and the fact that the right to freedom of expression is affected only indirectly by the rules governing the funding of political parties , and in view of the margin of appreciation which LAW , paragraph CARDINAL , affords the national legislature , the provisions of section CARDINAL of the LAW DATE are not incompatible either with the requirements of LAW , or indeed with those of LAW .
As regards Community law :

The applicant group argues that since the resources obtained by the funding association whose authorisation has been refused stem from a political party with its registered office in a member ORG of ORG , the provisions of the penultimate subsection of section CARDINAL of the LAW DATE , in so far as they apply to a situation governed by Community law , are incompatible with a number of provisions of the LAW establishing ORG .

Thirdly , even supposing that the rules governing the funding of political parties may , in certain respects , have a bearing on the free movement of capital between member States as guaranteed by LAW , that LAW CARDINAL clearly indicates , does not affect the right of member GPE to ‘ take measures which are justified on grounds of ... public security’ . Regard being had both to the aim it pursues and to the limited impact it has on the free movement of capital , the prohibition set forth in the penultimate subsection of LAW CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Act of CARDINAL March CARDINAL is to be counted among the measures that may be taken by a member ORG under LAW . Accordingly , the submission that the LAW is incompatible with LAW must be dismissed .

Fourthly , the provisions of section CARDINAL of the LAW DATE , which , as stated above , are intended to avoid creating any relationship of dependency between political parties in the performance of their function and a foreign ORG or a foreign legal entity , are likewise not incompatible with the provisions of LAW , which appear in a part of LAW dealing with the Community institutions and more specifically ORG , and which read : ‘ Political parties at NORP level are important as a factor for integration within the Union . They contribute to forming a NORP awareness and to expressing the political will of the citizens of the ORG Accordingly , and even supposing that Article CARDINAL creates any rights in respect of private individuals , this submission must fail . ... ”
CARDINAL . The first paragraph of LAW DATE provides :

“ Political parties and groups shall contribute to the exercise of suffrage . They shall be formed and carry on their activities freely . They shall respect the principles of national sovereignty and democracy . ”

Section CARDINAL of ORG ( Law no . CARDINAL . The financing of politics in general and political parties in particular is governed by law ( main source : technical files on the ORG ’s website , ORG ) .

CARDINAL . In addition to the operating costs they have to meet in the same way as any other association , political parties incur significant expenditure during election campaigns . They have CARDINAL main sources of funds : private funding , which is generally modest , and ORG funding , which nowadays accounts for a decisive share .
CARDINAL . Like any association , political parties may charge membership fees . In practice , however , these account for only a very small proportion of their resources .

CARDINAL . The Act of DATE ( as amended ) gives them the further possibility of receiving donations from individuals ( donations from other legal entities are in principle prohibited ) ; however , voluntary contributions from individuals are traditionally modest .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG of ORG adopted Recommendation DATE ) on the financing of political parties , the relevant parts of which read :

CARDINAL . The ORG believes that the rules on financing political parties and on electoral campaigns must be based on the following principles : a reasonable balance between public and private funding , fair criteria for the distribution of ORG contributions to parties , strict rules concerning private donations , a threshold on parties’ expenditures linked to election campaigns , complete transparency of accounts , the establishment of an independent audit authority and meaningful sanctions for those who violate the rules .
CARDINAL . Accordingly , the ORG considers that :
NORP As regards sources of finance

i. States should encourage ORG participation in the activities of political parties , including their financial support to parties . It should be accepted that membership fees , traditional and non - controversial sources of finance , are not sufficient to face the ever increasing expense of political competition .

ii . Political parties should receive financial contributions from the ORG budget in order to prevent dependence on private donors and to guarantee equality of chances between political parties . State financial contributions should , on the one hand , be calculated in ratio to the political support which the parties enjoy , evaluated on objective criteria such as the number of votes cast or the number of parliamentary seats won , and on the other hand enable new parties to enter the political arena and to compete under fair conditions with the more well - established parties .

iii . State support should not exceed the level strictly necessary to achieve the above objectives , since excessive reliance on ORG funding can lead to the weakening of links between parties and their electorate .

iv . Besides their financial contributions , GPE may contribute indirectly to financing political parties based on law , for example by covering the costs of postage and of meeting rooms , by supporting party media , youth organisations and research institutes ; and also by granting tax incentives .

v. PERSON with ORG funding , private funding is an essential source of finance for political parties . As private financing , in particular donations , creates opportunities for influence and corruption , the following rules should apply :
a. a ban on donations from ORG enterprises , enterprises under ORG control , or firms which provide goods or services to the public administration sector ;
b. a ban on donations from companies domiciliated in offshore centres ;
c. strict limitations on donations from legal entities ;
d. a legal limit on the maximum sum of donations ;
e. a ban on donations by religious institutions .
